HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FRIDAY, APRIL 5, 1935

Vol. XXXIX—No. 39

Jay Stickmen
Open Tomorrow
Vs. Dartmouth
Morrill Begins First Campaign As Head Coach; 5
Sophomores In Line-up

Elect Captain Today
Lettermen To Meet To Pick
Successor To Reynolds,
Absent This Semester
Tomorrow afternoon at 2.30, the
Jay stickmen blast the lid off the 1935
season at Homewood with the Dartmouth ten. Coach Kelso Morrill, on
the threshold of his first campaign as
head lacrosse coach, has not been willing to consider the Green an easy opponent, but their 15-1 loss to St.
Jonn's two days ago indicates that
such will be the case.
The exhibition that the Blue team,
with five sophomores in the line-up,
displays tomorrow will be called up
as a comparison between Hopkins and
what has been called the best St.
John's team since 1931.
New England Champs
Dartmouth, admitted to the United
States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association in 1927, has consistently been
one of the top northern teams. Last
year they were unofficial co-champions of New England, their sole collegiate loss being to Syracuse, a team
that St. John's had difficulty in beating.
The Green trounced Yale, Harvard,
and Hobart, and saw the Boston Lacrosse Club squeeze through to a 4-3
win. During that season, Dartmouth
scored 30 points to their opponents'
25. Unfortunately, they lost most of
their team, Halverson, first attack,
being about the only outstanding player left from last year.
Kels has revised his starting team,
still subject to change before game
time. The defense is the same—Naylor, Haberkorn, Swindell, and Pasarew, with Gilbert and Reuling still
having to face-off in the race for
goalie.
But the attack has been switched
around. Henry Houck, who has been
counting steadily from his midfield
post, has been moved in to out home,
shoving Bucky White out of the starting line-up.
Elect Captain Today

Cotillion Board To Aid
In Sweater Payments
April 20 has been set as the
date for the dance to be given by
the Cotillion Board of the University to raise the remainder of
the money necessary for the payment on the athletic sweaters.
Tickets to the dance, which will
be held in Levering Hall, will
probably be sold at $.50 a couple.
These will be placed on sale next
week.
The "gymboree," given last
February, did not raise enough
money for the purchase of the
sweaters, and members of the Co:illion Board hope to add the necessary money from the profits of
the dance, which will be used entirely for this purpose.

Simonds Calls Case
Hopeless For Peace
With PresentSet-Up
Declares U. S. Policies Have
Been Inconsistent On
Navy And Debts Questions
Characterizing international conferences as the "most
unreal
things" in politics, Dr. Frank H.
Simonds this week pointed out the
hopelessness of internatioral conciliation as long as ideas of peoples and
the present political and economic
arrangements remain.
He spoke
Tuesday, Wednesday, and yesterday
in Giiman Hall 310 as an Albert
Shaw lecturer on diplomatic history.
Taking as his subject "American
Foreign Policy in the Post-War
Years," Dr. Simonds on the first day
took up the subject of the Navy,
showing how the United States had
become a participant in the international arms race just previous to
and during the World War by its
acquiring of the Philippines and the
desire to protect them against possible attack by Japan; and later Trie
building of an enormous and unprecedented fleet during the War
caused Great Britain to seek parity
with the United States, since it
could no longer hope for superiority. The idea of parity has been re,tained by the United States ever
since the War, he said, and thus we
have become mixed up in the European race, since Great Britain's fleet
is maintained on a two-power basis,
that is, she tries to maintain a fleet
equal to those of any two other nations in Europe.
On the second day Dr. Simonds took
up the question of the army, pointing
out that it played only a small role
in the defenses of the U. S. He declared that Americans consider Europe to be militaristic and lacking in
idealism because the nations of the
Old World keep armies as the chief

Bill Provid ed Oath

Call Motive Dubious

No Placards Allowed

Committee Trying To Obtain
Endorsement Of Faculty, Mrs. Holloway Worked For
Passage Of Bill With The
Speakers, Other Groups
Daughters Of 1812 War
To the list of student organizations
backing the coming student strike
scheduled to occur on April 12, at 11
o'clock has been added the Barnstormers, represented by Alan Delevett and T. Bayard Williams. These
two students are now part of the
"committee on preparations", composed of Elijah Adams, Hamilton
Owens, Bert I. Gordon, and Tessim
Zorach, for the National Student
League; Ferdinand Engel for the
Hopkins chapter of the League
Against War and Fascism; and Neal
Potter, Irving Leberfeld, and Jesse
Borden for the NEWS-LETTER.
At a meeting of the N. S. L., held
April 2, the "committee on preparation's" decided that there would be
no placards carried during the strike.
The committee is trying to obtain the
endorsements of as many faculty
members as possible. Attempts are
also being made to secure prominent
members of the faculty and student
body as speakers. Some students not
affiliated with any group in the strike
may be asked to talk.
Campus organizations who are interested in the protest against war
have been urged to join the strike and
furnish speakers. Those who have already decided to sponsor the strike
have sent delegates to the "preparations committee". Letters have already been 'written to the Methodist
Youth groups in Baltimore and the
Goucher League for Industrial Democracy, urging them to sponsor or
endorse the strike.
The strike, initiated by the N. S.
L., will feature a cessation of all
campus activities for one hour, during which speeches will be delivered
to the assembled students. Tessim
Zorach heads the committee in charge
of the strike.

ROBINSON TO SPEAK
Students of history at Goucher
College will hear Dr. David M. Robinson, professor of archaeology, this
Monday, April 8, at 8 p. m.
Dr. Robinson will take as his topic, "Recent Excavations at Olynthus."

Declaring that the chief protests of
the Hopkins against the teachers'
oath bill could have been prevented
by the adoption of a bill which she introduced as chairman of the Defense
Committee of the Daughters of the
War of 1812, Mrs. Reuben Ross Holloway gave the blame to the American
Legion for introducing the bill which
was passed by the Legislature. She
stated, however, that she is giving her
support to the present measure.
In response to the question as to
what was meant by the "Oath of Allegiance" in the bill, she brought forth
a copy of the bill which she, with the
backing of a large number of patriotic
organizations had introduced, and
which had been "amended" to be the
present bill.
The bill of the Daughters of 1812
would have required all teachers to
take the following oath:
"I swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United
States of America, the Constitution of
the State of Maryland and the laws
of the United States of America and
the State of Maryland; and will by
precept and example, promote respect
for the flag and the institutions of the
United States of America and laws
of Maryland, reverence for law and
order, and undivided allegiance to the
government of the United States of
America."
In addition, the bill provided:
"That no person can qualify to
teach or lecture in"any school, college,
university, parochial school or educational institution in the State of
Maryland—to be a permanent employee until such person shall have
first taken the Oath (or affirmation)
of Allegiance to the flag and the Constitution of these United States of
America and the laws of Maryland.
"Any person who is a citizen or subject of any country other than the
United States of America, and who is
employed in any capacity as a professor, instructor or teacher in school,
college, university, parochial school
or educational institution in the State
of Maryland—before entering upon
the discharge of his or her duties—
shall subscribe to an oath to support

President Ames, Dr. Lovejoy
Lead Hopkins Opposition;
Seek Annapolis Hearing
Three telegrams and four petitions
gave evidence or the almost unanimous protest of the Hopkins, students and faculty alike, against the
teachers" oath bill passed by the
Maryland Legislature in its recent
session.
Immediate protest was registered
by President Ames, together with
Dr. Robertson, president of Goucher
College, and Hopkins professors as
soon as they learned of the passage
of the bill, which, if signed by Gov--Courtesy Sun papers
ernor Nice, would require all teachMRS. REUBEN ROSS HOLLOWAY
ers and lecturers in State-aided institutions to take an oath of allegiance to the United States before
they would be allowed to continue
their work. The telegram sent by
Dr. Ames with the professors requested the Governor not to sign the
bill until he had given them a hearing.

conferences, he declared that they are
fundamentally unreal, because •the
diplomats go to them already committed by politics at home to policies which are not only opposed, but

in view of their commitments and
political situations at home.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FRIDAY, APRIL 5, 1935

Vol. XXXIX—No. 39

Jay Stickmen
Open Tomorrow
Vs. Dartmouth
Morrill Begins First Campaign As Head Coach; 5
Sophomores In Line-up

Elect Captain Today
Lettermen To Meet To Pick
Successor To Reynolds,
Absent This Semester
Tomorrow afternoon at 2.30, the
Jay stickmen blast the lid off the 1935
season at Homewood with the Dartmouth ten. Coach Kelso Morrill, on
the threshold of his first campaign as
head lacrosse coach, has not been willing to consider the Green an easy opponent, but their 15-1 loss to St.
Jonn's two days ago indicates that
such will be the case.
The exhibition that the Blue team,
with five sophomores in the line-up,
displays tomorrow will be called up
as a comparison between Hopkins and
what has been called the best St.
John's team since 1931.
New England Champs
Dartmouth, admitted to the United
States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association in 1927, has consistently been
one of the top northern teams. Last
year they were unofficial co-champions of New England, their sole collegiate loss being to Syracuse, a team
that St. John's had difficulty in beating.
The Green trounced Yale, Harvard,
and Hobart, and saw the Boston Lacrosse Club squeeze through to a 4-3
win. During that season, Dartmouth
scored 30 points to their opponents'
25. Unfortunately, they lost most of
their team, Halverson, first attack,
being about the only outstanding player left from last year.
Kels has revised his starting team,
still subject to change before game
time. The defense is the same—Naylor, Haberkorn, Swindell, and Pasarew, with Gilbert and Reuling still
having to face-off in the race for
goalie.
But the attack has been switched
around. Henry Houck, who has been
counting steadily from his midfield
post, has been moved in to out home,
shoving Bucky White out of the starting line-up.
Elect Captain Today

Cotillion Board To Aid
In Sweater Payments
April 20 has been set as the
date for the dance to be given by
the Cotillion Board of the University to raise the remainder of
the money necessary for the payment on the athletic sweaters.
Tickets to the dance, which will
be held in Levering Hall, will
probably be sold at $.50 a couple.
These will be placed on sale next
week.
The "gymboree," given last
February, did not raise enough
money for the purchase of the
sweaters, and members of the Co:illion Board hope to add the necessary money from the profits of
the dance, which will be used entirely for this purpose.

Committee On Teachers' Oath Of Allegiance Bill;
Student Strike

Simonds Calls Case
Hopeless For Peace
With PresentSet-Up
Declares U. S. Policies Have
Been Inconsistent On
Navy And Debts Questions
Characterizing international conferences as the "most
unreal
things" in politics, Dr. Frank H.
Simonds this week pointed out the
hopelessness of internatioral conciliation as long as ideas of peoples and
the present political and economic
arrangements remain.
He spoke
Tuesday, Wednesday, and yesterday
in Giiman Hall 310 as an Albert
Shaw lecturer on diplomatic history.
Taking as his subject "American
Foreign Policy in the Post-War
Years," Dr. Simonds on the first day
took up the subject of the Navy,
showing how the United States had
become a participant in the international arms race just previous to
and during the World War by its
acquiring of the Philippines and the
desire to protect them against possible attack by Japan; and later Trie
building of an enormous and unprecedented fleet during the War
caused Great Britain to seek parity
with the United States, since it
could no longer hope for superiority. The idea of parity has been re,tained by the United States ever
since the War, he said, and thus we
have become mixed up in the European race, since Great Britain's fleet
is maintained on a two-power basis,
that is, she tries to maintain a fleet
equal to those of any two other nations in Europe.
On the second day Dr. Simonds took
up the question of the army, pointing

Delevett, Williams Added To
Group Of N.S. L.,'News- Claims Bill She Introduced
Letter', Anti-War League
Would Have Eliminated
A Great Many Protests

Goucher President Joins In
Demanding Veto From

Bill Provid ed Oath

Call Motive Dubious

No Placards Allowed

Committee Trying To Obtain
Endorsement Of Faculty, Mrs. Holloway Worked For
Passage Of Bill With The
Speakers, Other Groups
Daughters Of 1812 War
To the list of student organizations
backing the coming student strike
scheduled to occur on April 12, at 11
o'clock has been added the Barnstormers, represented by Alan Delevett and T. Bayard Williams. These
two students are now part of the
"committee on preparations", composed of Elijah Adams, Hamilton
Owens, Bert I. Gordon, and Tessim
Zorach, for the National Student
League; Ferdinand Engel for the
Hopkins chapter of the League
Against War and Fascism; and Neal
Potter, Irving Leberfeld, and Jesse
Borden for the NEWS-LETTER.
At a meeting of the N. S. L., held
April 2, the "committee on preparation's" decided that there would be
no placards carried during the strike.
The committee is trying to obtain the
endorsements of as many faculty
members as possible. Attempts are
also being made to secure prominent
members of the faculty and student
body as speakers. Some students not
affiliated with any group in the strike
may be asked to talk.
Campus organizations who are interested in the protest against war
have been urged to join the strike and
furnish speakers. Those who have already decided to sponsor the strike
have sent delegates to the "preparations committee". Letters have already been 'written to the Methodist
Youth groups in Baltimore and the
Goucher League for Industrial Democracy, urging them to sponsor or
endorse the strike.
The strike, initiated by the N. S.
L., will feature a cessation of all
campus activities for one hour, during which speeches will be delivered
to the assembled students. Tessim
Zorach heads the committee in charge
of the strike.

ROBINSON TO SPEAK
Students of history at Goucher
College will hear Dr. David M. Robinson, professor of archaeology, this
Monday, April 8, at 8 p. m.
Dr. Robinson will take as his topic, "Recent Excavations at Olynthus."

Declaring that the chief protests of
the Hopkins against the teachers'
oath bill could have been prevented
by the adoption of a bill which she introduced as chairman of the Defense
Committee of the Daughters of the
War of 1812, Mrs. Reuben Ross Holloway gave the blame to the American
Legion for introducing the bill which
was passed by the Legislature. She
stated, however, that she is giving her
support to the present measure.
In response to the question as to
what was meant by the "Oath of Allegiance" in the bill, she brought forth
a copy of the bill which she, with the
backing of a large number of patriotic
organizations had introduced, and
which had been "amended" to be the
present bill.
The bill of the Daughters of 1812
would have required all teachers to
take the following oath:
"I swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United
States of America, the Constitution of
the State of Maryland and the laws
of the United States of America and
the State of Maryland; and will by
precept and example, promote respect
for the flag and the institutions of the
United States of America and laws
of Maryland, reverence for law and
order, and undivided allegiance to the
government of the United States of
America."
In addition, the bill provided:
"That no person can qualify to
teach or lecture in"any school, college,
university, parochial school or educational institution in the State of
Maryland—to be a permanent employee until such person shall have
first taken the Oath (or affirmation)
of Allegiance to the flag and the Constitution of these United States of
America and the laws of Maryland.
"Any person who is a citizen or subject of any country other than the
United States of America, and who is
employed in any capacity as a professor, instructor or teacher in school,
college, university, parochial school
or educational institution in the State
of Maryland—before entering upon
the discharge of his or her duties—
shall subscribe to an oath to support

Lead Hopkins Opposition;
Seek Annapolis Hearing
Three telegrams and four petitions
gave evidence or the almost unanimous protest of the Hopkins, students and faculty alike, against the
teachers" oath bill passed by the
Maryland Legislature in its recent
session.
Immediate protest was registered
by President Ames, together with
Dr. Robertson, president of Goucher
College, and Hopkins professors as
soon as they learned of the passage
of the bill, which, if signed by Gov--Courtesy Sun papers
ernor Nice, would require all teachMRS. REUBEN ROSS HOLLOWAY
ers and lecturers in State-aided institutions to take an oath of allegiance to the United States before
they would be allowed to continue
their work. The telegram sent by
Dr. Ames with the professors requested the Governor not to sign the
bill until he had given them a hearing.

In criticism of international "peace"
conferences, he declared that they are
fundamentally unreal, because •the
diplomats go to them already committed by politics at home to policies which are not only opposed, but
mutually exclusive. Although editors
may, especially in the. United States,
think that agreements can
be
reached by simply stating over and
over again that the conference is going to be a success, it is inevitable
that it will fail, and the subsequent
blaming of the diplomats for failing
to come to an agreement is unjustified, since they do all that they can
in view of their commitments and
political situations at home.

Owing to the number of non-affiliated volley-ball enthusiasts in the
school, efforts are being made to
organize a four team spring volleyball league. The team, if formed,
will consist of those who are not
playing frat volley-ball. If enough
support is given to the idea, chances
are that there will be several
matches arranged with other teams
in the city, such as the Y. M. C. A.,
Y. M. H. A., B. A. C., and other
clubs. All those interested in the
formation of such a league shall
signify their intentions by dropping
a note in Box 981 or by seeing Reuben Baer.
